prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: science goal 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to observe 6 blazars in the region centred at RA=329 degree and Dec = 14 degree (J2000). All the sources are within 10 degrees and can be observed with individual pointings centred on the targets. Since, blazars exhibit significant flux variability at these frequencies, the proposed observations at the two frequencies have to be performed close enough in time i.e. within a week.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Most of these sources are in the ALMA calibrator source catalog. Therefore, we opt for system-defined calibration.
All the sources will be point like on the basis of our knowledge at these frequencies. For this reason, we proposed the desired resolution.

The expected peak flux densities are above 160 mJy at 233 GHz and 130 mJy at 343 GHz, respectively for all the sources. Assuming roughly 10% polarization in the sources (Agudo et al. 2014), an rms of 4 mJy at 233 GHz and 3 mJy at 343 GHz is adequate to allow detection of a polarized signal with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) > 4 even for the faintest objects.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: science goal 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to observe 6 blazars in the region centred at RA=-80 degree and Dec = 58 degree (J2000). All the sources are within 10 degrees and can be observed with individual pointings centred on the targets. Since, blazars exhibit significant flux variability at these frequencies, the proposed observations at the two frequencies have to be performed close enough in time i.e. within a week.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Most of these sources are in the ALMA calibrator source catalog. Therefore, we opt for system-defined calibration.
We are interested in the polarized emission from the compact core which will more look like as a point source.

The expected peak flux densities are above 160 mJy at 233 GHz and 130 mJy at 343 GHz, respectively for all the sources. Assuming roughly 10% polarization in the sources (Agudo et al. 2014), an rms of 4 mJy at 233 GHz and 3 mJy at 343 GHz is adequate to allow detection of a polarized signal with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) > 4 even for the faintest objects.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Fermi-Large Area Telescope (LAT) has revolutionized our knowledge of the -ray sky making remarkable discoveries. Most of the these sources are blazars - AGN in which one of the relativistic jets is pointed in the observers line-of-sight. However, a sizable population of known blazars are still missing their -ray counterpart which leads to an unexplored dichotomy of -ray loud and -ray quiet blazars. The key objectives of this research proposal are: (1) to explore the magnetic field structure and strength in the immediate vicinity of super-massive black holes in blazars using Faraday rotation measurements, and (2) to investigate the discrepancy between the polarization properties of gamma-ray loud and quiet blazars. We propose to observe a sample of 53 blazars (including 30 gamma-ray loud and 23 gamma-ray quiet blazars) in full polarization mode simultaneously at 233 GHz (Band 6) and 343 GHz (Band 7) radio frequencies with ALMA. The role of ALMA is unique in this context, as no other observatory offers simultaneous polarization observations at these frequencies, which are needed for the Faraday rotation measurements.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Centre for Space Research, North-West University
